lexUnit.name: charge.v
lexUnit.definition: COD: demand (an amount) as a price for a service rendered or goods supplied.

sentence.text: Operators earn 28p a minute for peak rate calls and 16p for cheap , with British Telecom charging the person who is responsible for the bill whether he made the call or not .
But London hotels can not expect to go on charging high prices when they can not even be bothered to welcome guests in their own language .
Except in a few cases , where the law states that a product must be sold at a fixed price ( ie all retailers must charge the same price ) , retailers can charge what they like !
` The companies can charge what they like for drugs , then be as inefficient as they like , and stay under the profit ceiling .
` Some products have too wide a variation to be explained by these factors and one must assume that many multi-national companies are charging what they believe the market will bear . "
Firms have a right to charge what the market will bear -- as long as it is a competitive market .
Clare baked nothing that could be found at the local baker and charged what she considered exorbitant prices , which people seemed happy to pay in cash .
Vicar wants to charge to go to church .
Charging to park on the playground can be a lucrative source of funds .
Meanwhile the surveyor , who is doing a ventriloquist act with his insurers , carries on with his surveys , charging higher fees to pay for his increased insurance premiums .
You just write WORLD LEADER in your passport , charge a fortune to expound views rejected by your people , and let the world , and the people , go to hell .
Nimslo will charge 9.99 to produce 18 prints ( 4 half-frame exposures are needed for each print ) .
Press leaks hinted that the government was considering means-testing the child benefit now paid to every mother and charging richer patients to use National Health Service hospital beds .

Nevertheless , there are often Possibilities for the supplier to charge different people different amounts for the same good based approximately upon marginal value , for example a fixed charge plus an amount dependent upon intensity of use .
Nutty found out that she charged ten pounds an hour .
So he 'd taken an upstairs room and divided it into six spaces , figuring he could charge 1.50 an hour for each of them and really coin it in .
REMEMBER we charge fines at 50p per item per week from closing time on the date stamped in the item .
Twice I 've picked up goods on a shelf marked reduced and then found , because of the bar codes , I was charged full price at the pay-out desk .
Mrs Ryan was cheerfully living on a steadily increasing overdraft , for which the bank was charging her interest at two per cent above the normal rate because the loan was unsecured .
Taxi rides are cheapest in Portugal , where the cabbies charge only 18p for a one-mile city trip .

SHOPS will soon be able to charge higher prices for goods bought by credit card , the Trade and Industry Secretary , Mr Nicholas Ridley , announced yesterday in a written reply to a parliamentary question .
After testing nine such cleaning firms , Which ? magazine found many charged high rates for poor quality service .

Solicitors and private doctors charge a set rate for their time so use it economically .

As we just remarked , banks charge interest on bank loans .

Unlike some of its competitors , XVT does not charge a royalty to developers converting their software and then selling it on to their own customers .
` Charge all future bills directly to me , " Cornelius said with a smile .

The new lender will charge its legal expenses to you .

If it 's done within the hour we charge the hour .
